fields.description:
This bug focuses on AWS compatibility.  EUCA-9965 took care of the initial issue, however the fix for it involved Eucalyptus ELB returning HTTP 503s.  This behavior doesn't match AWS.  The issue really shows up in use cases where application stacks based on ELB + ASG services.  The sporadic HTTP 503 responses happen for a period of time (roughly 5 minutes), then all responses are HTTP 200.  The verification used for EUCA-11606 will create this behavior 100%.  Below is an example of the behavior (seen when using curl against the ELB URL):

fields.summary: Eucalyptus ELB returns sporadic 503 responses when instances are registered/deregistered

comments.body: [~hspencer] Is there a cloud that I can reproduce this issue? Or can you illustrate the steps to recreate?

[~spark], apologies for the late response. The answer to both questions is yes.  I do have a cloud up and running right now, and the [steps are illustrated|https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/EUCA-11606?focusedCommentId=110301&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels%3Acomment-tabpanel#comment-110301] in EUCA-11606.  Let me know how you would like to proceed.  Thanks for checking this out.

[~hspencer] I debugged the system. The CF stack runs an ELB in 2 AZs and as a result two ELB VMs run in each AZ. Because cross-zone ELB is enabled, each ELB VM is given the backend instances in both zones. The root issue in that cloud is that the instance (ELB VM) in an AZ is not able to communicate with the (backend) instance in a different zone. So when haproxy running in the ELB VM is talking to the instance in the same zone, curl returns 200. In the next round, when haproxy tries to talk to the instance in the different zone, it returns 503. So it's not ELB-specific issue, but a general VPC issue (either specifically in that Cloud or global). I don't see why two instances in different zones in the same VPC fails to communicate via their private IP.
[~spark], we should check that the route tables look right for the subnets (perhaps a difference in behaviour since EUCA-11571 was implemented)

[~spark], ah okay.  Whats interesting is that it initially starts out sending 503s, but then after a period of time, 200s are consistently returned.  This behavior happens after both scaling out and scaling in of the Auto Scaling group.  I wonder what causes the issue to 'resolve' itself after a period of time (e.g. ~5+ minutes).
[~spark], each route table is independent, so there is no conflict.

[~hspencer] There's health check thread running in the VM that pings the backend instance. Eventually the instance that haproxy can't reach is excluded from the service (so effectively cross-zone loadbalancing is not perfomed in that cloud). One thing strange is that it takes too long to remove those unrecheable (cross AZ) instances (20 min in my test). It could be that ping went through for some initial period of time and then stopped...
[~spark], I thought we used 10.254.0.0/16 or 192.168.0.0/16 for elb vpcs?
[~sjones] Yes, they are the system VPCs and the issue is in the user's VPC (data channel).
Would you mind re-testing? Fix is pushed.
